lines.text: Do you think you'd be afraid if you saw... a ghost? These ghosts would appear to you very much like ordinary people... children of your own age, or even an old man, such as myself.
[the children are keen to see some real ghosts]
As they grow older they lose their power to believe in the unlikely.
[about the Allen's new home]
Ghoulies and ghosties and long-leggedy beasties, that place 'as got 'em.
Please let us be happy here... and don't let there be any ghosts.
You can be a ghost, but you don't have to be dead.
Thirty thousand pounds if 'e snuffs it!
They must not run away, Mrs. Wickens. Lock them up!
Someone is trying to tell us how to escape; not to another place, but to another time.
[the children try to discover if a substance is poisonous]
I'm not giving it to her because I think it is poison, I'm only making sure it isn't! Why are you pulling a funny face? It's either Mrs. Wickens or her cat, and that cat never did anyone any harm!
I have suffered for 100 years... tormented by my own conscience. It seemed more like a thousand years.
Please, don't be dead. Sara, wake up!
Miss Sara. Is she alright?
They're alive, but I can't wake them up, Tom. They've been drugged!

[Standing at the bottom of the burning staircase trying to rescue Georgie]
I would if I could. I would, Georgie, I would!
At last! At last! Thank you, my dears.
James, we will go together. The fire will not touch you... Now is the time. Look straight ahead, and don't be afraid.
You're too late, Mr. Blunden! You're always too late!

[Talking to the house]
It's all very well for you, you'll belong to somebody again. But what about us? Where do we belong?
Poor books. How sad.
It's pleased, Georgie. The library is pleased!

[To Sara]
Do stop sniveling in front of the servants. It will do no good!
Are you Smith?
I beg your pardon?
Are you Smith? Blunden, Claverton and Smith.
No sonny-jim, I am Mr. Clutterbug.
You should be pleased.
Why?
No one could forget a name like that.
[leaves]
It is a silly name.
I'm sorry... sir.
We three kings of Orient are my dears!
Now where's she going for her honeymoon like she says; Paris, Rome... even if its only the Isle of Wight for God's sake put her out of her misery!
It may well be the Isle of Wight dear mother-in-law.
The Isle of Wight? God strewth!
Steady dearest. The truth is financially I am hopelessly embarassed, hopelessly, I haven't said so as I had no wish to spoil our wedding day.
Well you're having a darn good try Albert!
You can't grin if you've got no head...
